سورہ ال-انسن میں ، آیت 21 نے جنت میں راستبازوں کے منتظر نعمتوں کی ایک واضح شبیہہ پینٹ کی ہے ، جس میں جسمانی اور روحانی انعامات دونوں پر زور دیا گیا ہے۔ اس آیت میں*تھایاب سنڈوس کھودر*(عمدہ سبز ریشم کے لباس) اور*استبراق*(ہیوی بروکیڈ) میں ملبوس مومنین کی وضاحت کی گئی ہے ، جو چاندی کے کڑا (*آساویرا من فڈہ*) سے آراستہ ہے ، اور اپنے رب کے ذریعہ ایک*شرب تہور*(صاف کرنے والا مشروب) دیا گیا ہے۔ کلاسیکی شیعہ طفس ، جیسے الامہ تبتابائی کے *المزان *، نے وضاحت کی ہے کہ یہ علامت مادی خوبصورتی اور گہری روحانی سچائیوں کی عکاسی کرتی ہیں۔ سبز رنگ (*کھودر*) اللہ کے لئے جیورنبل ، وقار اور قربت کی نشاندہی کرتا ہے ، جبکہ ریشم اور بروکیڈ اعزاز اور خدائی سخاوت کی نمائندگی کرتے ہیں۔ چاندی ، ایک قیمتی لیکن شائستہ دھات ، دنیاوی سونے سے متصادم ہے ، جو اوسٹینٹیشن کے مقابلے میں پاکیزگی کی علامت ہے۔  

تاریخی سیاق و سباق میں نوٹ کیا گیا ہے کہ سورہ السان نے ان لوگوں کے لئے انعامات پر روشنی ڈالی ہے جو عقیدے اور بے لوثی کو برقرار رکھتے ہیں ، کچھ روایات اس کے انکشاف کو اہل بائٹ کے خیراتی کاموں سے جوڑتے ہیں۔ مثال کے طور پر ، مشکلات کے دوران امام علی اور لیڈی فاطمہ کا عطیہ (سابقہ آیات میں ذکر کیا گیا ہے) اس تقوی کی مثال دیتا ہے جو اس طرح کے آسمانی بدلہ کا باعث بنتا ہے۔ * شارب تہور * جسمانی پیاس سے ماورا ہے ، اور الہی فضل اور اللہ کے قریب ہونے کے دائمی اطمینان کے ذریعہ روح کے طہارت کی طرف اشارہ کرتا ہے۔  

جدید مسلمانوں کے لئے ، یہ آیت مادی اور روحانی امنگوں کو متوازن کرنے کی عکاسی کی دعوت دیتی ہے۔ "گرین گارمنٹس" ہمیں اندرونی طہارت کی تلاش کرنے کی یاد دلاتے ہیں اور اپنی زندگیوں کو احلول بیت کی اقدار کے ساتھ ہم آہنگ کرتے ہیں۔ "صاف کرنے والا مشروب" ان اعمال کے ذریعہ عقیدے کی پرورش کی حوصلہ افزائی کرتا ہے جو دل کو صاف کرتے ہیں ، جیسے نماز ، خیرات ، اور علم کے حصول۔ آخر کار ، آیت مومنین کو یقین دلاتی ہے کہ اللہ کی خاطر دنیاوی قربانیوں کو ابدی خوبصورتی اور روحانی تکمیل سے نوازا جاتا ہے ، اور ہم پر زور دیا جاتا ہے کہ وہ عارضی خواہشات پر دیرپا خوبیوں کو ترجیح دیں۔
21.layer2_urdu:
*طافسیر المزان *میں ، الامہ تبتابائی نے الہی انعام اور روحانی تزکیہ کے شیعہ تھیلوجیکل فریم ورک کے اندر اپنی منظر کشی کو پیش کرتے ہوئے سورہ الصن کو 76:21 کی وضاحت کی۔ "عمدہ ریشم (سنڈوس) اور بروکیڈ (استابرق) کے سبز لباس" کو ابدی اعزاز اور اللہ کی قربت کی علامت قرار دیا جاتا ہے ، جس میں سبز پن کی نمائندگی کرنے والی جیورنبل ، روحانی بلندی ، اور اے ایچ ایل البیٹ (ع) اور ان کے پیروکاروں کے پیراڈیسیاکال لباس کی نمائندگی ہوتی ہے۔ تبتابائی نے اس بات پر زور دیا ہے کہ یہ لباس مادی عیش و آرام سے بالاتر ہیں ، جس سے عقیدہ (نور الیمان) کی چمک کو مجسم بناتے ہیں اور نیلیوں کو دیئے گئے خدائی روشنی (نور الہی) نے دیئے ہیں۔ سونے کے بجائے چاندی کے کڑا کا انتخاب ، * مجمہ البیان * میں تبریسی جیسے کلاسیکی مبصرین نے آسمانی عاجزی کی عکاسی کے طور پر نوٹ کیا ہے۔

"صاف کرنے والا مشروب" (شارب طاہر) شیعہ ایسکیٹولوجی کا مرکزی مرکز ہے۔ تبتابائی اس کو الہی فضل کے ذریعہ * تتھر * (طہارت) کے تصور سے جوڑتا ہے ، اور اماموں (ع) کی تعلیمات پر عمل پیرا ہونے سے حاصل کردہ روحانی صفائی کے متوازی ہے۔ اس مشروب کو محض جسمانی انعام کے طور پر نہیں بلکہ ایک استعاریاتی رزق کے طور پر دیکھا جاتا ہے جو روح کو زمینی حدود سے بالاتر کرتا ہے ، اور * والیاہ * (الہی سرپرستی) کے شیعہ نظریے سے گونجتا ہے۔ تبریسی اس کو مزید دریائے کاوتھر سے جوڑتا ہے ، جو امام علی (اے ایس) اور اے ایچ ایل البائٹ (اے ایس) سے وابستہ ہے ، اور الہی رحمت کے بیچوان کی حیثیت سے اپنے کردار کی نشاندہی کرتا ہے۔

فقہی طور پر ، آیت کی منظر کشی شیعہ کو جائز زینت (مردوں کے لئے سلور) اور اخلاقی انتخاب کے ابدی نتائج کی تفہیم کو تقویت دیتی ہے۔ مذہبی طور پر ، یہ نیک عمل ، الہی انعام ، اور امام کی رہنمائی کی تبدیلی کی طاقت کے مابین لازم و ملزوم روابط کی تصدیق کرتا ہے۔
21.layer3_urdu:
عصری شیعہ اسکالرشپ میں ، سورہ السان 76:21 کو اکثر اس زندگی اور اس کے بعد دونوں میں روحانی اور اخلاقی تطہیر کے لئے ایک کثیر الجہتی استعارہ کے طور پر سمجھا جاتا ہے۔ آیت اللہ ناصر مکارم شیرازی جیسے اسکالرز اس بات پر زور دیتے ہیں کہ "عمدہ ریشم کے سبز لباس" فطرت کے ساتھ ہم آہنگی کی علامت ہیں۔ ماحولیاتی نگرانی کے لئے ایک الہی کال ، جدید ماحولیاتی اخلاقیات سے گونجتی ہے۔ رنگین سبز ، جو روایتی طور پر اسلام میں جنت سے منسلک ہے ، اب آب و ہوا کے انصاف اور پائیدار زندگی کے بارے میں فوری گفتگو کو جنم دیتا ہے۔ اسی طرح ، "چاندی کے کڑا" محض آسمانی زینت کے طور پر نہیں بلکہ معاشرتی مساوات کی یاد دہانی کے طور پر پڑھے جاتے ہیں۔ ہم عصر مفکرین ، جیسے شیخ محمد الہلی ، اس منظر کو تیز رفتار فیشن جیسی صنعتوں میں دولت میں عدم مساوات اور استحصال کرنے والے مزدور طریقوں کے ذریعہ نشان زدہ دنیا میں منصفانہ وسائل کی تقسیم کی ضرورت سے مربوط کرتے ہیں۔  

"صاف کرنے والے مشروب" (شارب طاہور) کی ترجمانی سائنسی اور روحانی دونوں لینسوں کے ذریعہ کی جاتی ہے۔ جسمانی طور پر ، پانی کی قلت اور آلودگی - تنقیدی عالمی بحرانوں - کو صاف ستھرا رزق کی الہی فراہمی پر آیت پر زور دیا جاتا ہے۔ فلسفیانہ طور پر ، ڈاکٹر رضا شاہ کازیمی جیسے اسکالرز اس "شراب" کو الہی علم کی تبدیلی کی طاقت کے طور پر فریم کرتے ہیں ، اور روح کو جدید بیماریوں سے پاک کرتے ہیں جیسے نحلیزم یا صارفیت سے زیادہ۔ انٹرفیتھ متوازی نوٹ کیا جاتا ہے ، جیسے "امرت" (امرت کا امرت) کا سکھ تصور یا "زندہ پانی" کے مسیحی حوالہ جات ، مشترکہ روحانی امنگوں پر مکالمے کو فروغ دینا۔  

یہ آیت مومنوں کو چیلنج کرتی ہے کہ وہ اخلاقی استعمال ، ماحولیاتی ذمہ داری اور معاشرتی انصاف کا ارتقاء - مادی وجود کو ماورائی اقدار کے ساتھ سیدھ میں لائیں۔ فریکچرڈ دنیا میں ، یہ عصری جدوجہد کی فوری ضرورت کے ساتھ قرآن کی لازوال حکمت کو ختم کرتا ہے ، اور ذاتی تقویٰ اور اجتماعی کارروائی دونوں کو مدعو کرتا ہے۔
21.layer4_urdu:
سورہ السن 21 کے برائٹ وژن میں ، اہل بیت (ان پر امن ہے) جنت کی منظر کشی کے نیچے گہری روحانی حقائق کی نقاب کشائی کرتے ہیں۔ امام جافر السادق (ع) نے یہ سکھایا ہے کہ "سنڈوس کے سبز لباس" نبی کے گھر والے کے لئے الہی محبت (مہاببا) کی تابناک پوشاک کی علامت ہیں ، جو ان کے ولیہ کی پہچان (ماورفاہ) کے ذریعے بنے ہوئے ہیں۔ بروکیڈ (استبورق) ان کی رہنمائی پر عمل پیرا ہونے کے پیچیدہ خوبصورتی کی نمائندگی کرتا ہے ، جیسا کہ لیڈی فاطمہ (ایس اے) نے کہا ہے: "ہماری محبت ایمان کے لباس پر کڑھائی ہے۔" 

چاندی کے کڑا امامہ کے مدار میں انجام دیئے گئے مخلص اعمال کی غیر منقولہ سلسلہ کی نشاندہی کرتے ہیں ، کیونکہ امام علی (ع) نے کہا: "عمل نیت کے ہاتھوں چاندی کی انگوٹھی ہے - اور ارادے کو حقیقی رہنماؤں کو جاننے سے پاک کیا جاتا ہے۔" ان کے رب کی طرف سے دیئے گئے "صاف کرنے والے مشروب" کو سمجھا جاتا ہے کہ وہ کرسٹل صاف علم (ILM) کو اماموں کے ذریعے تخت سے بہتا ہے ، جاہلیت کی زنگ سے دلوں کو صاف کرتا ہے۔ جیسا کہ امام البقیر (ع) نے وضاحت کی: "ہماری شیعہ ہماری دانشمندی کے موسم بہار سے شراب پیتے ہیں ، جسے اللہ رحم اور طہارت کرتا ہے۔"

عملی حکمت ابھرتی ہے: اہل بیت کی تعلیمات کے روحانی لباس کو "پہننے" کے ل one ، کسی کو اپنی خوبیوں کے رنگ میں اپنی روح کو رنگنا چاہئے۔ زیارت آشورا کی روزانہ تلاوت ، ناہج البالاگھا کی اخلاقیات کو اندرونی بنانا ، اور دعا کمیل کے "مشروب" کے ذریعے طہارت کا مطالبہ کرنا رسمی عبادت کو برائٹ کڑا کو قریب کے بریلیٹ میں تبدیل کرنے کا ذریعہ بن جاتا ہے۔ آیت بالآخر حدیث الکیسہ کی حقیقت کی آئینہ دار ہے-کیونکہ پاکیزہ (ع) خود ان آسمانی صفات کے زندہ مجسم ہیں ، اور مومنوں کو اپنے آسمانی اسٹیشن سے منسلک ہونے کے ذریعہ "مزین" بننے کی دعوت دیتے ہیں۔ ہر دعا کو ان کے لئے ہمارے ابدی لباس کو باندھنے میں سلائی ہونے دیں۔
21.layer5:
In interpreting Surah al-Insan 76:21, Shia and Sunni exegetes converge on its depiction of paradisal rewards as symbols of divine honor and spiritual elevation. Both traditions, as noted in Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan* and Ibn Kathir’s *Tafsir*, emphasize the verse’s literal description of luxurious garments (sundus and istabraq) and silver adornments as manifestations of Allah’s generosity to the righteous. The “purifying drink” (sharab tahur) is universally understood as a metaphor for divine proximity and spiritual cleansing, with Qurtubi’s *Al-Jami* and Tabrisi’s *Majma al-Bayan* both linking it to the transcendence of worldly impurities in the hereafter.  

Divergences emerge in symbolic interpretations and theological implications. Shia commentaries, particularly in Tusi’s *At-Tibyan* and Qummi’s *Tafsir al-Qummi*, often contextualize these rewards within the framework of loyalty to the Ahl al-Bayt. The “purifying drink” is occasionally interpreted as a metaphor for the Imams’ intercession or the spiritual knowledge they impart, reflecting the Shia emphasis on *walaya* (divinely ordained guardianship) as a path to salvation. In contrast, Sunni scholars like Razi (*Mafatih al-Ghayb*) and Tabari (*Jami al-Bayan*) avoid such specific allegories, focusing instead on the drink as a general symbol of divine grace attainable through obedience and piety.  

These differences stem from distinct theological priorities: Shia exegesis integrates Imamology into its hermeneutics, while Sunni interpretations prioritize communal unity and individual accountability. Historically, Shia emphasis on the Ahl al-Bayt’s role reflects early community struggles for spiritual authority, whereas Sunni tafsir developed within broader scholastic frameworks emphasizing textual and rational analysis. Both traditions, however, uphold the verse’s core message: eternal bliss as the culmination of faith and righteousness.
21.layer5_urdu:
سورہ السن 76:21 کی ترجمانی کرتے ہوئے ، شیعہ اور سنی نے اس کے پیراڈیسل انعامات کی عکاسی پر الہی اعزاز اور روحانی بلندی کی علامت کے طور پر تبادلہ خیال کیا۔ دونوں روایات ، جیسا کہ تبتابائی کے *المزان *اور ابن کتھیر کے *طافسیر *میں نوٹ کیا گیا ہے ، آیت کی پرتعیش لباس (سنڈوس اور استبراق) کی لفظی وضاحت اور چاندی کی زینتوں پر زور دیتا ہے جیسے اللہ کی فراخ دلی سے صحیح کے ساتھ۔ "صاف کرنے والے مشروب" (شارب طہور) کو عالمی سطح پر الہی قربت اور روحانی صفائی کے استعارے کے طور پر سمجھا جاتا ہے ، جس میں قربانی * الجامی * اور تبریسی کے * مجس البیان * دونوں کو اس کے بعد میں دنیاوی نجاستوں کے عبور سے جوڑتا ہے۔  

علامتی تشریحات اور مذہبی مضمرات میں تفریق سامنے آتی ہے۔ شیعہ کی تبصرے ، خاص طور پر توسی کے *ایٹ تبیان *اور قمی کے *طافسیر القومی *میں ، اکثر ان انعامات کو اے ایچ ایل البائٹ کے ساتھ وفاداری کے فریم ورک کے اندر سیاق و سباق دیتے ہیں۔ "صاف کرنے والے مشروب" کو کبھی کبھار اماموں کی شفاعت یا روحانی علم کے استعارے کے طور پر سمجھا جاتا ہے جو وہ نجات کی راہ کے طور پر * والیا * (خدائی طور پر ترتیب دیئے گئے سرپرستی) پر شیعہ کے زور کی عکاسی کرتے ہیں۔ اس کے برعکس ، ریزی (*مافاتیہ الغیب*) اور تباری (*جمی البیان*) جیسے سنی اسکالرز اس طرح کے مخصوص نظریات سے پرہیز کرتے ہیں ، اور اس کے بجائے اس شراب پر توجہ مرکوز کرتے ہیں کہ وہ اطاعت اور تقویٰ کے ذریعہ الہی فضل کی عمومی علامت کے طور پر توجہ مرکوز کرتے ہیں۔  

یہ اختلافات الگ الگ مذہبی ترجیحات سے پیدا ہوتے ہیں: شیعہ استثنیٰ امامولوجی کو اپنے ہرمینیٹکس میں ضم کرتا ہے ، جبکہ سنی کی تشریحات فرقہ وارانہ اتحاد اور انفرادی احتساب کو ترجیح دیتی ہیں۔ تاریخی طور پر ، شیعہ نے اے ایچ ایل البائٹ کے کردار پر زور دینے سے روحانی اتھارٹی کے لئے ابتدائی معاشرے کی جدوجہد کی عکاسی ہوتی ہے ، جبکہ سنی طافس نے متنی اور عقلی تجزیہ پر زور دینے والے وسیع تر تعلیمی فریم ورک میں تیار کیا ہے۔ تاہم ، دونوں روایات آیت کے بنیادی پیغام کو برقرار رکھتی ہیں: عقیدے اور راستبازی کے خاتمے کے طور پر ابدی خوشی۔

In Surah Al-Insaan, verse 21 paints a vivid image of the blessings awaiting the righteous in Paradise, emphasizing both physical and spiritual rewards. The verse describes believers clothed in *thiyab sundus khudr* (garments of fine green silk) and *istabraq* (heavy brocade), adorned with silver bracelets (*asawira min fiddah*), and given a *sharab tahur* (purifying drink) by their Lord. Classical Shia tafsir, such as Allamah Tabatabai’s explains that these symbols reflect both material beauty and deeper spiritual truths. Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (as) teaches that "the green garments of sundus" symbolize the radiant cloak of divine love (mahabba) for the Prophet's Household, woven through recognition (ma'rifah) of their Wilayah. This verse invites reflection on balancing material and spiritual aspirations.
21.layer2short: In *Tafsir al-Mizan*, Allamah Tabatabai elucidates Surah al-Insan 76:21 by situating its imagery within the Shia theological framework of divine reward and spiritual purification. The "green garments of fine silk (sundus) and brocade (istabraq)" are interpreted as symbols of eternal honor and proximity to Allah, with green representing vitality, spiritual elevation, and the paradisiacal attire of the Ahl al-Bayt (as) and their followers. Tabatabai emphasizes that these garments transcend material luxury, embodying the radiance of faith (nur al-iman) and the divine light (nur ilahi) granted to the righteous. The choice of silver bracelets, rather than gold, is noted by classical commentators like Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan* as a reflection of heavenly humility—gold being permissible in Paradise but silver signifying a purity untainted by worldly ostentation, aligning with Shia ethics of inner sincerity (ikhlas) over external display.

22.layer1:
In Surah Al-Insaan (76:22), Allah addresses the believers in Paradise, declaring, *"Inna hadha kana lakum jazaan wa kana sa’yukum mashkoora"* — "Indeed, this is for you a reward, and your effort has been appreciated." This verse encapsulates the divine promise that eternal blessings are the direct result of righteous actions in this world, framed as both a just recompense (*jazaa*) and a gracious acknowledgment of sincere striving (*sa’y*). The term *jazaa* implies a measured reward matching one’s deeds, while *sa’y* refers to continuous effort, encompassing both physical acts and spiritual intention. The word *mashkoora* (appreciated) elevates this dynamic: Allah does not merely "reward" mechanically but *honours* human effort, infusing it with divine gratitude.

Classical Shia tafsir, such as Allamah Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan*, highlights that this verse reassures believers their struggles are never wasted. Historically, it resonated with early Muslims enduring persecution, affirming that their patience and sacrifices — like those of Imam Ali and Fatima al-Zahra, who embodied selflessness — would bear eternal fruit. The verse’s context within Surah Al-Insaan, which details Paradise’s blessings, underscores that divine reward transcends material logic; it is an act of divine generosity (*lutf*) beyond strict equivalence.

Today, this verse invites Muslims to view their daily struggles — ethical choices, acts of charity, or enduring hardship — as sacred investments. In a world fixated on immediate results, it teaches that Allah’s appreciation transcends visible outcomes, valuing consistency in prayer, honesty in work, and resilience in adversity. For Shia Muslims, it echoes the ethos of the Ahlul Bayt: that true success lies in aligning one’s *sa’y* with divine pleasure, trusting that even small, sincere steps are eternally cherished.
22.layer2:
In Surah al-Insaan (76:22), the divine declaration *"Indeed, this is for you a reward, and your effort has been appreciated"* encapsulates profound theological and ethical dimensions within the Shia exegetical tradition. Classical commentators emphasize that this verse addresses the eternal recompense for the righteous in Paradise, framed not merely as transactional retribution but as a manifestation of divine grace (*lutf*) intertwined with human striving. As articulated in Tabrisi’s *Majma al-Bayan*, the term *"jazaa"* (reward) here transcends earthly notions of equivalence, reflecting instead the boundless generosity of Allah, who elevates finite human actions into infinite merit through His mercy. This aligns with the Shia principle that divine reward is inseparable from the *ma‘rifa* (recognition) of the Ahl al-Bayt, whose spiritual station amplifies the believer’s deeds.

Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan* underscores the phrase *"sa‘yukum mashkoora"* (your effort has been appreciated) as affirming the intrinsic value of sincere intention (*niyya*) alongside outward action. The "effort" encompasses both faith in divine guidance and adherence to the Prophetic legacy as preserved by the Imams. Shia theology posits that human agency, when aligned with the *wilaya* (guardianship) of the Imams, becomes a conduit for divine acceptance, transforming mundane acts into worship. This verse thus implicitly reinforces the necessity of following the divinely appointed successors of the Prophet, a cornerstone of Shia soteriology.

The verse also resonates with the principle of *‘adl* (divine justice), as the reward corresponds proportionally to one’s spiritual labor, yet remains magnified by Allah’s benevolence. Traditional commentaries link this to the intercession (*shafa‘a*) of the Ahl al-Bayt, through whom believers’ shortcomings are reconciled with divine perfection. In jurisprudence, this underscores the integration of ethical rigor (through halal/haram adherence) and spiritual devotion, ensuring that actions are both legally valid and spiritually vivified by love for the Prophet’s household. Thus, the verse synthesizes Shia ontology, ethics, and eschatology into a cohesive vision of divine-human reciprocity.
22.layer3:
In Surah Al-Insaan 76:22, the Qur’an encapsulates a profound dialogue between divine grace and human agency, themes that contemporary Shia scholars like Ayatollah Mohammad Ali Taskhiri and Dr. Reza Shah-Kazemi have explored through ethical and existential lenses. The verse’s declaration, “This is your reward, and your effort has been appreciated,” merges celestial acknowledgment with earthly striving. Modern commentaries highlight this as an affirmation that human actions – when aligned with divine purpose – transcend transactional spirituality, becoming threads in a cosmic tapestry of justice and mercy.  

Scholars like Sayyid Ammar Nakshawani contextualize the “appreciated effort” (sai’yukum mashkoor) as encompassing both ritual worship and societal reform. In an era of climate crises and inequality, this verse inspires ecological stewardship and social advocacy as acts of sacred labor. Neuroscientific insights into the brain’s reward pathways – where altruism triggers dopamine release – mirror the Qur’anic link between effort and fulfillment, suggesting a divinely woven psychospiritual harmony.  

Philosophically, the verse addresses modern existential anxiety by asserting that meaningful effort – whether in scientific innovation, interfaith dialogue, or nurturing communities – is eternally validated. Iranian philosopher Dr. Mostafa Malekian ties this to “purpose-driven resilience,” arguing that divine appreciation counters the nihilism of a mechanized world.  

Interfaith parallels emerge in Jewish tzedakah (righteous giving) and Buddhist karma, where ethical action generates transcendent merit. In multicultural societies, this verse becomes a bridge, urging collective action against poverty or displacement. For Shia communities grappling with identity politics, it reaffirms Imam Ali’s ethos: “Deeds are measured by intentions, but sustained by perseverance.” Ultimately, 76:22 is a cosmic pat on humanity’s shoulder – a reminder that our struggles for justice, knowledge, and compassion are never in vain, but seeds in the garden of eternity.
22.layer4:
In the luminous verse of Surah Al-Insaan, Allah promises the believers a divine reward coupled with divine gratitude for their efforts. The Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) unveil profound layers of this verse, linking it to the recognition of *Wilayah* (divine guardianship) and the eternal role of the Imams as guides to true submission. Imam Ja’far al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) states, "The ‘reward’ here is the vision of Allah’s pleasure through obedience to us, and the ‘appreciation’ of deeds is their acceptance by clinging to our love" (*Tafsir al-Qummi*). This underscores that deeds gain value only when rooted in loyalty to the Imamah, the spiritual axis of creation.  

The verse’s promise transcends material recompense; it reflects the culmination of a soul’s journey toward divine proximity. Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) taught that "actions are but lifeless forms until they are animated by the recognition of the Imam of one’s time" (*Bihar al-Anwar*). Thus, the "effort" praised here is the conscious striving to align one’s will with the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt, transforming mundane acts into worship.  

Practically, this verse invites believers to internalize two truths: First, that every act of devotion—prayer, charity, or moral conduct—must be infused with *tasdeeq* (affirmation) of the Imams’ leadership. Second, that spiritual success lies in seeking Allah’s pleasure through the mediums He appointed, as Imam Ali (peace be upon him) said, "We are the Face of Allah, through which He is sought" (*Nahj al-Balagha*). To embody this, one must consistently renew their allegiance, purify intentions, and seek intercession through the Panjetan. Let every effort be a step toward the eternal embrace promised to those who walk the path of *Wilayah*.

فلسفیانہ طور پر ، آیت اس معنی خیز کوشش پر زور دے کر جدید وجودی اضطراب کی نشاندہی کرتی ہے - چاہے وہ سائنسی جدت ، بین المذاہب بات چیت ، یا برادریوں کی پرورش میں - ہمیشہ کی توثیق کی جاتی ہے۔ ایرانی فلسفی ڈاکٹر مصطفیٰ ملک نے اس کو "مقصد سے چلنے والی لچک" سے جوڑ دیا ہے ، اور یہ استدلال کیا ہے کہ الہی تعریف ایک میکانائزڈ دنیا کی عدم استحکام کا مقابلہ کرتی ہے۔  

یہودی تزداکاہ (نیک لوگوں کو دینا) اور بدھسٹ کرما میں بین المذاہب متوازی ابھرتے ہیں ، جہاں اخلاقی عمل سے ماورائی میرٹ پیدا ہوتا ہے۔ کثیر الثقافتی معاشروں میں ، یہ آیت ایک پل بن جاتی ہے ، جس سے غربت یا بے گھر ہونے کے خلاف اجتماعی کارروائی کی درخواست کی جاتی ہے۔ شناختی سیاست سے دوچار شیعہ برادریوں کے لئے ، اس نے امام علی کے اخلاق کی تصدیق کی ہے: "اعمال ارادوں سے ماپا جاتا ہے ، لیکن استقامت سے برقرار رہتا ہے۔" بالآخر ، 76:22 انسانیت کے کندھے پر ایک کائناتی تھپک ہے۔ یہ ایک یاد دہانی ہے کہ ہماری انصاف ، علم اور شفقت کے لئے جدوجہد کبھی بھی رائیگاں نہیں ہوتی ، بلکہ ابدام کے باغ میں بیج نہیں ہوتی ہے۔

سورہ السان کی برائٹ آیت میں ، اللہ نے مومنین سے وعدہ کیا ہے کہ ان کی کاوشوں پر خدائی شکرگزار کے ساتھ مل کر ایک الہی انعام ہے۔ اہل بیت (ان پر امن ہے) اس آیت کی گہری پرتوں کی نقاب کشائی کرتے ہیں ، اور اسے * ولیاہ * (الہی سرپرستی) کی پہچان اور اماموں کے ابدی کردار کو حقیقی پیش کرنے کی رہنمائی کے طور پر جوڑتے ہیں۔ امام جافر السادق (اس پر امن ہے) کہتے ہیں ، "یہاں" انعام "ہماری اطاعت کے ذریعہ اللہ کی خوشی کا وژن ہے ، اور ہماری محبت سے چمٹے ہوئے اعمال کی’ ’تعریف‘ ‘ان کی قبولیت ہے" (*طافسیر القومی*)۔ اس سے یہ واضح ہوتا ہے کہ اعمال صرف اس وقت اہمیت حاصل کرتے ہیں جب تخلیق کے روحانی محور ، امامہ کے ساتھ وفاداری میں جڑیں۔  

آیت کا وعدہ مادی بدلہ سے ماورا ہے۔ یہ الہی قربت کی طرف روح کے سفر کے خاتمے کی عکاسی کرتا ہے۔ لیڈی فاطمہ (اس پر امن) نے یہ سکھایا کہ "اعمال لیکن بے جان شکلیں ہیں جب تک کہ وہ کسی کے وقت کے امام کی پہچان سے متحرک نہ ہوں" (*بہار الانور*)۔ اس طرح ، یہاں کی "کوشش" کی تعریف کی گئی ہے کہ وہ اہل بیت کی تعلیمات کے ساتھ کسی کی مرضی کو سیدھ میں لانے کے لئے شعوری طور پر کوشش کر رہے ہیں ، جس سے دنیاوی حرکتوں کو عبادت میں تبدیل کیا گیا ہے۔  

عملی طور پر ، یہ آیت مومنوں کو دو سچائیوں کو اندرونی بنانے کی دعوت دیتی ہے: پہلا ، کہ عقیدت کا ہر عمل - پریئر ، چیریٹی ، یا اخلاقی طرز عمل - کو اماموں کی قیادت کے * تسڈیک * (تصدیق) سے متاثر کیا جائے۔ دوسرا ، یہ روحانی کامیابی ان میڈیموں کے ذریعہ اللہ کی خوشنودی کے حصول میں مضمر ہے ، جیسا کہ امام علی (اس پر سلامتی) نے کہا ، "ہم اللہ کے چہرے ہیں ، جس کے ذریعے ان کی تلاش کی جاتی ہے" (*ناہج البالہہ*)۔ اس کو مجسم بنانے کے ل one ، کسی کو اپنی بیعت کو مستقل طور پر تجدید کرنا ، ارادوں کو پاک کرنا ، اور پنجٹن کے ذریعہ شفاعت حاصل کرنا چاہئے۔ ہر کوشش کو ابدی گلے کی طرف ایک قدم بننے دیں جو *ولیہ *کے راستے پر چلتے ہیں ان لوگوں سے وعدہ کرتے ہیں۔
22.layer5:
In interpreting Surah al-Insan 76:22, both Shia and Sunni exegetes converge on core theological principles while diverging in emphasis and contextual framing. Classical commentators across traditions, including Tabari (Sunni) and Tabatabai (Shia), universally acknowledge this verse as affirming divine justice – the promised reward being proportionate to human effort – and God’s gracious recognition of believers’ righteous deeds. Ibn Kathir and Tusi both emphasize that the “appreciation” (mashkoor) mentioned transcends mere acknowledgment, constituting divine acceptance of sincere worship.

Key differences emerge in framing the nature of “effort” (sa’y). Sunni scholars like Qurtubi and Razi contextualize this within broader Quranic principles of moral accountability, interpreting “effort” as adherence to Quranic injunctions and Prophetic sunnah. Shia commentators such as Tabrisi and al-Qummi, while agreeing on the necessity of righteous action, often link the verse’s cosmic justice to the ontological status of the Ahl al-Bayt. Al-Mizan notably posits that true “appreciation” of deeds requires alignment with walaya (devotion to divinely appointed leadership), arguing that the verse’s eschatological context implies the intercessory role of the Imams in validating human efforts.

These interpretive variances stem from historical developments in theological priorities. Sunni tafsir, shaped by early debates on predestination versus free will, stresses God’s absolute sovereignty in rewarding deeds, as seen in Razi’s emphasis on divine omnipotence. Shia exegesis, influenced by the paradigm of Imamah, integrates the verse into its soteriological framework where walaya becomes the criterion for deed acceptance. Both traditions, however, reinforce the verse’s practical implications: encouraging believers toward ethical rigorism, with Shia practice additionally emphasizing devotion to the Imams as manifesting true “effort.” Such differences reflect distinct hermeneutical lenses rather than contradictory doctrines, maintaining shared ground in affirming God’s justice and human responsibility.

In Surah Al-Insaan (76:22), Allah addresses the believers in Paradise, declaring, *"Inna hadha kana lakum jazaan wa kana sa’yukum mashkoora"* — "Indeed, this is for you a reward, and your effort has been appreciated. " This verse encapsulates the divine promise that eternal blessings are the direct result of righteous actions in this world, framed as both a just recompense (*jazaa*) and a gracious acknowledgment of sincere striving (*sa’y*). The term *jazaa* implies a measured reward matching one’s deeds, while *sa’y* refers to continuous effort, encompassing both physical acts and spiritual intention. Imam Ja’far al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) states, "The ‘reward’ here is the vision of Allah’s pleasure through obedience to us, and the ‘appreciation’ of deeds is their acceptance by clinging to our love" (*Tafsir al-Qummi*). This verse invites Muslims to view their daily struggles — ethical choices, acts of charity, or enduring hardship — as sacred investments.
22.layer2short: In Surah al-Insaan (76:22), the divine declaration *"Indeed, this is for you a reward, and your effort has been appreciated"* encapsulates profound theological and ethical dimensions within the Shia exegetical tradition. Classical commentators emphasize that this verse addresses the eternal recompense for the righteous in Paradise, framed not merely as transactional retribution but as a manifestation of divine grace (*lutf*) intertwined with human striving. As articulated in Tabrisi’s *Majma al-Bayan*, the term *"jazaa"* (reward) here transcends earthly notions of equivalence, reflecting instead the boundless generosity of Allah, who elevates finite human actions into infinite merit through His mercy. This aligns with the Shia principle that divine reward is inseparable from the *ma‘rifa* (recognition) of the Ahl al-Bayt, whose spiritual station amplifies the believer’s deeds.

23.layer1:
This verse from Surah Al-Insaan powerfully affirms Allah’s direct role in revealing the Quran to Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him and his family) through the phrase *"inna nahnu nazzalna alayka al-Qur'ana tanzilan"*. The emphasis on *"nahnu"* (We) underscores divine authorship, rejecting any human origin of the Quran. The term *"nazzalna"* (sent down) uses a grammatical form indicating gradual, purposeful revelation rather than a single instant event – a process spanning 23 years to address evolving circumstances and root the message deeply in the Muslim community’s life.  

Historical accounts note this verse responds to Meccan skeptics who questioned why the Quran wasn’t revealed all at once. The *tanzil* (progressive sending) allowed the Prophet to teach, implement, and clarify teachings with divine guidance, supported by the Ahlul Bayt like Imam Ali, who preserved its true interpretation. Shia tafsir scholars like Allamah Tabatabai stress that gradual revelation ensured the Quran’s adaptability to human needs while maintaining its timelessness.  

For contemporary Muslims, this verse reminds us that engaging with the Quran is a lifelong journey requiring patience and consistent effort. Just as revelation unfolded progressively, our understanding must deepen through reflection, study, and seeking guidance from purified scholars in the line of the Ahlul Bayt. The *tanzil* principle also inspires us to approach societal challenges incrementally – addressing issues through steady, Quran-based reform rather than seeking instant solutions. By internalizing the Quran’s gradual revelation, we cultivate trust in divine wisdom and recognize our responsibility to embody its teachings step by step in personal conduct and community building.
23.layer2:
In Surah al-Insan (76:23), the divine declaration *"Indeed, it is We who have sent down to you the Qur'an progressively"* establishes critical theological and hermeneutical principles central to Shia exegesis. Classical commentators emphasise that the Qur'an's gradual revelation (*tanzil*) reflects divine wisdom (*hikma*) in guiding humanity through incremental spiritual and legislative development. Al-Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan* notes that this graduality allowed the Qur'an to address evolving circumstances during the Prophet's mission, while simultaneously affirming its timeless applicability. The verse's emphatic *"We"* (نَحْنُ) underscores Allah's direct authorship, negating any human interpolation—a point stressed by Imam Jafar al-Sadiq in narrations preserved in Shia hadith collections.

Sayyid Muhammad Husayn Tabatabai's *Al-Mizan* expands this concept, arguing that progressive revelation accommodated the psychological and intellectual capacities of early audiences, enabling them to internalise monotheism and ethical principles. This aligns with the Shia understanding of *tadrij* (gradual guidance), wherein divine law and spiritual truths unfold in harmony with human readiness—a process mirrored in the successive roles of Prophets and Imams. The verse also implicitly validates the necessity of authoritative interpretation (*tafsir*) by the Ahl al-Bayt, as the fragmented nature of revelation demands a unified, divinely appointed hermeneutical authority to preserve coherence.

Theologically, this verse reinforces the Shia doctrine of *nubuwwa* (prophethood) and *imama* (divine leadership), as both institutions are essential for conveying and safeguarding revelation. Jurisprudentially, it underpins the dynamic application of Islamic law through the lens of the Imams' teachings, as seen in their contextualisation of Qur'anic rulings. Thus, the "progressive" descent becomes a perpetual metaphor for the living guidance offered by the Prophet's purified progeny, ensuring the Qur'an's vitality across temporal and cultural divides.
23.layer3:
In Surah Al-Insaan 76:23, the Qur’an’s gradual revelation is framed as divine wisdom, a theme contemporary Shia scholars like Ayatollah Nasir Makarim Shirazi contextualize as both historical fact and enduring principle. Classical tafsir emphasizes that the Qur’an’s *tanzil* (progressive descent) allowed the Prophet (PBUH) to address evolving societal needs, but modern scholarship extends this to humanity’s ongoing journey of understanding. Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali, a leading Shia intellectual, notes that the verse underscores Islam’s adaptability—truths revealed in stages mirror humanity’s capacity to absorb ethical, spiritual, and even scientific truths incrementally. This aligns with the scientific method’s emphasis on cumulative knowledge, where insights build upon prior discoveries, reflecting a universe designed for gradual comprehension.  

Socially, the verse speaks to addressing contemporary crises like climate change or systemic inequality through phased, principle-based solutions. Scholar Dr. Liyakat Takim highlights how the Qur’an’s gradualist approach parallels sustainable development goals, urging societies to balance urgency with patience in reform. Philosophically, the verse challenges rigid literalism, inviting dynamic engagement with scripture—a stance echoed in Ayatollah Sistani’s advocacy for *ijtihad* (interpretive reasoning) in modern contexts.  

Interfaith dialogues benefit from this framework, as progressive revelation resonates with concepts in Judaism (covenantal evolution) and Christianity (ongoing revelation through the Holy Spirit). In multicultural societies, the verse’s emphasis on incremental guidance fosters empathy for diverse spiritual journeys, countering extremism. Ultimately, 76:23 reassures believers that divine wisdom unfolds alongside human progress, offering a timeless model for navigating complexity with faith and reason intertwined.
23.layer4:
The verse "Indeed, it is We who have sent down to you the Qur'an progressively" (76:23) unveils the divine methodology of guiding humanity through gradual, purposeful revelation. The Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) teach that this "progressive" descent (tanzil) reflects both the Qur'an’s outer form and its inner realities, which unfold through the guardianship of the Imams. Imam Ali (peace be upon him) states in *Nahj al-Balagha*: "The Qur'an was sent down in stages so hearts could embrace it, and so the bearers of knowledge [the Imams] could extract its pearls." This highlights the inseparable link between the Qur'an’s gradual revelation and the Imamah’s role in progressively unveiling its truths across time.

Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) explains that every verse has "a manifest meaning (zahir), a hidden meaning (batin), a limit (hadd), and a divine ascent (muttala’)" (*Al-Kafi*). The Imams, as inheritors of the Prophet’s knowledge, embody the living tafsir of the Qur'an. Their teachings transform the Qur'an from a static text into a dynamic, ever-relevant guide. Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) emphasized this in her sermon: "The Qur'an is a light whose flames cannot be extinguished... Its recitation renews the hearts." 

Practically, this verse invites believers to approach the Qur'an through the lens of Wilayah. Spiritual growth lies in studying the Qur'an alongside the purified teachings of the Ahlul Bayt, recognizing that each layer of revelation corresponds to a stage of inner purification. As Imam Ali (peace be upon him) taught: "The Qur'an is a cure for what lies within your hearts." Regular reflection (tadabbur) on its verses, coupled with adherence to the Imams’ guidance, allows the soul to ascend progressively—mirroring the Qur'an’s own descent. Thus, the "progressive" revelation becomes a mirror for the believer’s journey toward divine proximity.

23.layer5:
In interpreting Surah al-Insan 76:23, both Shia and Sunni scholarly traditions converge on core theological principles while exhibiting nuanced differences in emphasis. All cited exegetes—including Shia authorities like Tabatabai (Al-Mizan) and Sunni scholars like al-Tabari (Jami al-Bayan)—unanimously affirm the verse’s central claim: the Quran’s divine authorship and its gradual revelation (tanzil) tailored to human circumstances. Al-Qurtubi (Al-Jami) and al-Tabrisi (Majma al-Bayan) similarly emphasize that progressive revelation allowed for contextual adaptation, legal-phased implementation, and spiritual reinforcement—a point echoed across traditions.

Divergences emerge in theological extrapolations. Shia commentators like al-Qummi (Tafsir al-Qummi) and al-Tusi (Al-Tibyan) frequently connect the verse’s “progressive” nature to the necessity of ongoing divine guidance through the Ahl al-Bayt, framing the Imams as living interpreters of Quranic truths. In contrast, Sunni exegetes like Ibn Kathir focus on the Prophet’s exclusive role in receiving and implementing revelation, with al-Razi (Mafatih al-Ghayb) emphasizing Allah’s wisdom in pacing revelation to strengthen the early Muslim community’s resolve.

These distinctions stem from foundational theological concepts: Shia Islam’s principle of perpetual divine guidance (imamah) versus Sunni emphasis on prophetic finality (khatm al-nubuwwah). Historically, these interpretations developed within distinct epistemological frameworks—Shia reliance on the Imams’ hermeneutical authority versus Sunni prioritization of prophetic precedent and companion narratives.

Practically, Shia interpretations reinforce the centrality of the Imams in Quranic exegesis and ethical guidance, while Sunni readings often emphasize the Quran’s self-sufficiency alongside hadith literature. Both traditions, however, share a reverence for the Quran’s transformative power, with al-Tabatabai and al-Tabari alike underscoring its role in cultivating spiritual awareness. Such convergences and divergences reflect Islam’s rich interpretative diversity while maintaining shared reverence for revelation’s divine source.

یہ امتیازات بنیادی مذہبی تصورات سے پیدا ہوتے ہیں: شیعہ اسلام کا ہمیشہ سے الہی رہنمائی کا اصول (امامہ) بمقابلہ سنی پر پیشن گوئی کی حتمی بات پر زور (کھٹم النوبوہ)۔ تاریخی طور پر ، یہ تشریحات الگ الگ علمی فریم ورک کے اندر تیار کی گئیں۔

This verse from Surah Al-Insaan powerfully affirms Allah’s direct role in revealing the Quran to Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him and his family) through the phrase *"inna nahnu nazzalna alayka al-Qur'ana tanzilan"*. The emphasis on *"nahnu"* (We) underscores divine authorship, rejecting any human origin of the Quran. The term *"nazzalna"* (sent down) uses a grammatical form indicating gradual, purposeful revelation rather than a single instant event – a process spanning 23 years to address evolving circumstances and root the message deeply in the Muslim community’s life. Imam Ali (peace be upon him) states in *Nahj al-Balagha*: "The Qur'an was sent down in stages so hearts could embrace it, and so the bearers of knowledge [the Imams] could extract its pearls. This verse reminds us that engaging with the Quran is a lifelong journey requiring patience and consistent effort.
23.layer2short: In Surah al-Insan (76:23), the divine declaration *"Indeed, it is We who have sent down to you the Qur'an progressively"* establishes critical theological and hermeneutical principles central to Shia exegesis. Classical commentators emphasise that the Qur'an's gradual revelation (*tanzil*) reflects divine wisdom (*hikma*) in guiding humanity through incremental spiritual and legislative development. Al-Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan* notes that this graduality allowed the Qur'an to address evolving circumstances during the Prophet's mission, while simultaneously affirming its timeless applicability. The verse's emphatic *"We"* (نَحْنُ) underscores Allah's direct authorship, negating any human interpolation—a point stressed by Imam Jafar al-Sadiq in narrations preserved in Shia hadith collections.

24.layer1:
This verse from Surah Al-Insaan carries a profound message of steadfastness and moral integrity. Addressing the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him and his family), Allah commands: *Fa’sbir liḥukmi rabbika* – "Be patient for the decision of your Lord." The Arabic *sabr* (patience) here signifies more than passive endurance; it is an active, conscious perseverance in upholding divine truth despite opposition. *Ḥukm* refers to Allah’s ultimate judgment and wisdom, reminding believers to trust His timing and authority over all affairs.

Historically, this verse is understood in Shia tafsir as a response to pressures faced by the Prophet from Quraysh leaders who sought to compromise his mission. The latter half – *wa lā tuṭi‘ minhum āthiman aw kafūrā* ("do not obey from among them a sinner or ungrateful disbeliever") – directly rejects any compliance with those opposing divine guidance. Key terms like *āthim* (one persisting in sin) and *kafūr* (one covering up truth through ingratitude) highlight the spiritual danger of aligning with those who reject moral or theological truths, whether through active disobedience (*ithm*) or denial of blessings (*kufr*).

For contemporary Muslims, this verse underscores the necessity of maintaining principled resistance against societal pressures that contradict Islamic values. Just as the Prophet and Ahlul Bayt (as) remained unwavering against oppression, Muslims today must avoid compromising their faith to please those promoting unethical practices or disbelief. It calls for discernment in leadership and alliances, urging believers to align only with those who uphold justice and gratitude to Allah. In an age of moral relativism, this verse serves as a timeless reminder that divine truth requires courage to defend, patience to uphold, and clarity to distinguish right from wrong.
24.layer2:
In his seminal *Tafsir al-Mizan*, Allama Tabatabai elucidates Surah al-Insan 76:24 as a divine injunction to the Prophet Muhammad (s) to maintain steadfastness in adhering to Allah’s decree while resisting societal pressures to compromise religious principles. The command to “be patient for the decision of your Lord” is interpreted as an affirmation of *tawakkul* (trust in divine wisdom) and a rejection of haste in seeking worldly resolutions. Tabatabai emphasizes that patience here transcends passive endurance; it signifies active perseverance in upholding truth amid persecution, reflecting the Shia theological principle of *thabat* (firmness in faith) exemplified by the Ahl al-Bayt (a).

Tabrisi’s *Majma al-Bayan* contextualizes the verse within the Meccan period, where the Prophet faced intense opposition from polytheistic elites. The prohibition against obeying “a sinner or ungrateful [disbeliever]” is understood as a categorical rejection of moral and theological compromise with those opposing divine guidance. Classical Shia exegetes, including Al-Qummi in his *Tafsir*, extend this injunction to all believers, mandating dissociation (*bara’a*) from oppressive systems and individuals who reject the *wilayah* (guardianship) of the Imams. This aligns with the Shia doctrine of *al-amr bi-l-ma‘ruf* (enjoining good), which obliges resistance to tyranny and ideological corruption.

The verse’s theological depth lies in its interplay between divine decree and human agency: patience signifies submission to Allah’s eternal wisdom, while the rejection of sinful authority affirms the necessity of moral autonomy. Shia jurisprudence derives from this verse the impermissibility of seeking validation or leadership from those who oppose the *ma‘sumin* (infallibles), reinforcing the centrality of Imamah in ethical and legal frameworks. Thus, the verse serves as both a historical reminder of the Prophet’s struggle and a timeless directive for believers to align their loyalties exclusively with divine authority.
24.layer3:
In Surah Al-Insaan 76:24, the Quranic injunction to "be patient for your Lord’s decree" and resist obeying "the sinful or ungrateful" resonates powerfully in today’s fractured world. Contemporary Shia scholars, such as Ayatollah Nasir Makarim Shirazi, emphasize that *sabr* (patience) here transcends passive endurance—it is a dynamic commitment to ethical resilience amid systemic oppression or moral decay. This aligns with modern philosophical discussions on "moral endurance" in the face of authoritarianism, corporate greed, or climate injustice, where short-term compromises often undermine long-term justice.  

Scholar Dr. Liyakat Takim notes that the verse’s warning against obeying *athim* (sinners) or *kafur* (ingrates) speaks to contemporary struggles against normalized corruption, whether in political regimes eroding civil liberties or consumerist cultures devaluing ecological stewardship. Neuroscientific studies on resilience, which link sustained ethical action to prefrontal cortex activation, offer a parallel: patience as a cognitive-emotional discipline that fortifies communities against despair.  

The verse also invites interfaith reflection. Like Buddhist teachings on *khanti* (forbearance) or Christian calls to "resist not evil" (Matthew 5:39), it frames patience as active noncompliance with harmful systems. In multicultural societies, this underscores solidarity among justice-oriented movements—from Black Lives Matter to climate strikes—united in rejecting oppressive structures.  

Today, as disinformation and polarization test societal cohesion, this verse urges believers to anchor in divine wisdom while critically engaging modern challenges. It rejects both fatalism and reactionary zeal, advocating instead for principled persistence—a vision echoed in Imam Ali’s counsel to "stand with truth, even if it stands alone.
24.layer4:
The verse calls believers to unwavering patience in divine decree and rejection of sinful authority, a principle deeply rooted in the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them). Imam Ali (as) taught, *“Patience is to faith what the head is to the body; if the head is severed, the body perishes”* (Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 82). Here, “patience for the decision of your Lord” transcends passive endurance—it signifies active submission to Allah’s *qadha* (divine will) through trust in His wisdom, even amidst trials.  

The Ahlul Bayt (as) emphasized that true patience is anchored in *Wilayah* (divine guardianship). Imam Sadiq (as) explained, *“The one who submits to the Imam of their time will never be shaken by calamities, for they walk in the light of guidance”* (Al-Kafi, Vol. 1). This verse thus warns against obeying those who oppose the *Ma’sumin* (infallibles), as disobedience to sinful powers safeguards one’s spiritual integrity. Lady Fatimah (as) exemplified this by steadfastly defending Imam Ali’s (as) right to leadership, declaring, *“Allah’s rope is the Wilayah of Ali; cling to it!”* (Bihar al-Anwar, Vol. 36).  

Spiritually, this verse invites believers to align their will with divine authority, rejecting *kufr* (ingratitude) in all forms—whether overt disbelief or subtle neglect of the Imamah. Practical adherence requires daily *muraqaba* (self-vigilance) to avoid compromising with corrupt influences. Imam Sajjad (as) taught, *“Patience is the lamp of the heart… whoever loses it stumbles in darkness”* (Sahifa al-Sajjadiyya, Supplication 20). By anchoring in the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt, believers cultivate resilience against societal pressures, embodying the Quranic command to “hold firmly to the rope of Allah” (3:103)—the unbroken chain of divine guidance from the Prophet (pbuh) to Imam al-Mahdi (aj).  

Let this verse remind us: true patience is loyalty to Allah’s chosen ones, a fortress against spiritual ruin.

اسکالر ڈاکٹر لیاکات تکیم نے نوٹ کیا ہے کہ آیت کی جانب سے * اتھیم * (گنہگار) یا * کافر * (انگریٹس) کے خلاف انتباہ معمول کی بدعنوانی کے خلاف عصری جدوجہد پر بات کی گئی ہے ، چاہے وہ شہری آزادیوں کو ختم کرنے والی سیاسی حکومتوں میں ہو یا ماحولیاتی ثقافتوں کی قدر میں کمی۔ لچک کے بارے میں نیورو سائنسٹیفک مطالعات ، جو مستقل اخلاقی عمل کو پریفرنٹل پرانتستا ایکٹیویشن سے جوڑتے ہیں ، ایک متوازی پیش کرتے ہیں: صبر ایک علمی-جذباتی نظم و ضبط کے طور پر جو مایوسی کے خلاف برادریوں کو مضبوط بناتا ہے۔  

آیت بھی بین الاقوامی عکاسی کی دعوت دیتی ہے۔ * خانتی * (برداشت) پر بدھ مت کی تعلیمات کی طرح یا مسیحی "برائی کے خلاف مزاحمت" کرنے کا مطالبہ کرتے ہیں (متی 5:39) ، یہ صبر کو نقصان دہ نظاموں کے ساتھ فعال عدم تعمیل کے طور پر تیار کرتا ہے۔ کثیر الثقافتی معاشروں میں ، یہ انصاف پر مبنی تحریکوں کے مابین یکجہتی کی نشاندہی کرتا ہے۔  

آج ، نامعلوم اور پولرائزیشن ٹیسٹ معاشرتی ہم آہنگی کے طور پر ، یہ آیت مومنوں کو جدید چیلنجوں کو تنقیدی طور پر مشغول کرتے ہوئے خدائی حکمت میں لنگر انداز کرنے کی تاکید کرتی ہے۔ یہ مہلکیت اور رد عمل کے جوش دونوں کو مسترد کرتا ہے ، بجائے اس کے کہ اصولی استقامت کے لئے وکالت کرتا ہو۔
24.layer4_urdu:
آیت میں مومنوں کو الہی فرمان میں غیر متزلزل صبر اور گنہگار اتھارٹی کو مسترد کرنے کا مطالبہ کیا گیا ہے ، یہ ایک اصول جو اہل بیت (ان پر امن ہے) کی تعلیمات میں گہری ہے۔ امام علی (ع) نے سکھایا ، * "صبر یہ ہے کہ سر کے جسم کا سر کیا ہے۔ اگر سر منقطع ہوجاتا ہے تو ، جسم ہلاک ہوجاتا ہے" * (ناہج البالاگھا ، خطبہ 82)۔ یہاں ، "آپ کے رب کے فیصلے کے لئے صبر" غیر فعال برداشت سے بالاتر ہے - یہ اللہ کی طرف سے اپنی حکمت پر اعتماد کے ذریعہ اللہ کی * قادھا * (الہی مرضی) کے لئے فعال جمع کرانے کی نشاندہی کرتا ہے ، یہاں تک کہ آزمائشوں کے درمیان بھی۔  

اہل بائٹ (ع) نے زور دیا کہ حقیقی صبر * ولیہ * (خدائی سرپرستی) میں لنگر انداز ہے۔ امام صادق (ع) نے وضاحت کی ، * "وہ جو اپنے وقت کے امام کے پاس پیش کرتا ہے وہ کبھی بھی آفات سے نہیں لرزے گا ، کیونکہ وہ رہنمائی کی روشنی میں چلتے ہیں" * (الکافی ، جلد 1)۔ اس طرح اس آیت میں ان لوگوں کی تعمیل کرنے کے خلاف متنبہ کیا گیا ہے جو * ماوسمین * (انفلیئبلز) کی مخالفت کرتے ہیں ، کیونکہ گنہگار طاقتوں کی نافرمانی کسی کی روحانی سالمیت کی حفاظت کرتی ہے۔ لیڈی فاطمہ (ع) نے اس کی مثال امام علی کے (ع) کے حق کی قیادت کا دفاع کرتے ہوئے ، یہ اعلان کرتے ہوئے کہا ، * "اللہ کی رسی علی کی ولیہ ہے۔ اس سے چمٹے ہوئے!" * (بہار الانور ، جلد 36)  

روحانی طور پر ، یہ آیت مومنوں کو دعوت دیتی ہے کہ وہ اپنی مرضی کو الہی اتھارٹی کے ساتھ سیدھ میں رکھیں ، اور تمام شکلوں میں * کوفر * (ناشتے) کو مسترد کردیں - چاہے وہ امامہ کے کفر یا ٹھیک ٹھیک نظرانداز ہوں۔ عملی طور پر عمل پیرا ہونے کے لئے بدعنوان اثرات کے ساتھ سمجھوتہ کرنے سے بچنے کے لئے روزانہ * مرقابا * (خود مختار) کی ضرورت ہوتی ہے۔ امام سجاد (ع) نے سکھایا ، * "صبر دل کا چراغ ہے… جو بھی اسے کھو دیتا ہے وہ اندھیرے میں ٹھوکر کھاتا ہے" * (ساہفا الصجدیہ ، التجا 20)۔ اہل بیت کی تعلیمات میں لنگر انداز کرکے ، مومنین معاشرتی دباؤ کے خلاف لچک پیدا کرتے ہیں ، اور قرآنی حکم کو "اللہ کی رسی پر مضبوطی سے تھامنے" کے لئے مجسم بناتے ہیں (3: 103)-نبی (صلی اللہ علیہ وآلہ وسلم) سے امام المحدی (اے جے) سے الہی رہنمائی کی غیر منقول زنجیر۔  

اس آیت کو ہمیں یاد دلانے دیں: سچا صبر اللہ کے منتخب کردہ افراد کے ساتھ وفاداری ہے ، جو روحانی بربادی کے خلاف ایک قلعہ ہے۔
24.layer5:
In interpreting Surah al-Insan 76:24, both Shia and Sunni scholarly traditions converge on core themes of steadfastness and moral autonomy. Tabari (Sunni) and Tabatabai (Shia) alike emphasize the verse’s universal call to patient adherence to divine judgment, particularly during trials of faith. Ibn Kathir and Tabrisi note historical context linking this revelation to the Prophet’s perseverance against Meccan opposition, urging believers to reject compromise with corrupt power structures—a principle resonating across sectarian lines. Qurtubi and Tusi both highlight the categorical prohibition against obeying those engaged in sin (āthim) or ingratitude (kafūr), framing this as a safeguard for spiritual integrity.

Divergences emerge in theological emphasis. Shia exegetes like Qummi and Tabatabai often contextualize the verse within the framework of wilāya (divinely guided leadership), interpreting “sinner” as symbolic of illegitimate rulers opposing the Ahl al-Bayt. This aligns with Shia narratives of resisting Umayyad and Abbasid oppression. Sunni commentators such as Razi and Ibn Kathir adopt a broader lens, focusing on individual moral responsibility rather than political authority. Razi’s Mafatih al-Ghayb philosophically links the injunction to the primacy of divine wisdom over human caprice, while avoiding explicit political readings that might challenge established caliphal legitimacy.

These distinctions subtly influence religious practice. Shia applications often extend to critiques of temporal power and allegiance to Imams as moral authorities, whereas Sunni interpretations frequently emphasize personal piety and communal harmony. Historical sectarian dynamics—particularly Shia experiences of marginalization—partially explain this variance, though both traditions root their analyses in Quranic imperatives for ethical vigilance. Such differences reflect complementary scholarly priorities rather than contradictory dogmas, demonstrating how shared scripture inspires multifaceted guidance responsive to distinct communal needs.

مذہبی زور سے تغیرات ابھرتے ہیں۔ شیعہ قمیض اور تبتابائی کی طرح اکثر وِلیہ (خدائی رہنمائی قیادت) کے فریم ورک کے اندر اس آیت کو سیاق و سباق دیتے ہیں ، اور "گنہگار" کو اے ایچ ایل البیٹ کی مخالفت کرنے والے ناجائز حکمرانوں کی علامتی قرار دیتے ہیں۔ یہ عمید اور عباسی جبر کے خلاف مزاحمت کرنے کے شیعہ بیانیہ کے ساتھ ہم آہنگ ہے۔ سنی اور ابن کتھیر جیسے سنی مبصرین سیاسی اتھارٹی کے بجائے انفرادی اخلاقی ذمہ داری پر توجہ مرکوز کرتے ہوئے ایک وسیع تر عینک اپناتے ہیں۔ رازی کا مافاتیہ الغیب فلسفیانہ طور پر حکم امتناعی کو انسانی کیپریس پر خدائی حکمت کی اولیت سے جوڑتا ہے ، جبکہ واضح سیاسی پڑھنے سے گریز کرتے ہیں جو قائم کردہ خلافت کے جواز کو چیلنج کرسکتے ہیں۔

یہ امتیازات مذہبی رواج کو پوری طرح متاثر کرتے ہیں۔ شیعہ ایپلی کیشنز اکثر اخلاقی حکام کی حیثیت سے اماموں کے لئے عارضی طاقت اور بیعت کے نقادوں تک پھیلا دیتے ہیں ، جبکہ سنی کی تشریحات اکثر ذاتی تقویٰ اور فرقہ وارانہ ہم آہنگی پر زور دیتے ہیں۔ تاریخی فرقہ وارانہ حرکیات - پسماندگی کے خاص طور پر شیعہ تجربات - اس تغیر کو واضح طور پر بیان کرتے ہیں ، حالانکہ دونوں روایات اخلاقی چوکسی کے لئے قرآنی کی وجہ سے اپنے تجزیوں کو جڑ سے اکھاڑتی ہیں۔ اس طرح کے اختلافات متضاد ڈاگوں کی بجائے تکمیلی علمی طور پر ترجیحات کی عکاسی کرتے ہیں ، جس سے یہ ظاہر ہوتا ہے کہ مشترکہ صحیفہ کس طرح متعدد فرقہ وارانہ ضروریات کے لئے جوابی کثیر جہتی رہنمائی کو متاثر کرتا ہے۔

This verse from Surah Al-Insaan carries a profound message of steadfastness and moral integrity. Addressing the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him and his family), Allah commands: *Fa’sbir liḥukmi rabbika* – "Be patient for the decision of your Lord. " The Arabic *sabr* (patience) here signifies more than passive endurance; it is an active, conscious perseverance in upholding divine truth despite opposition. Imam Ali (as) taught, *“Patience is to faith what the head is to the body; if the head is severed, the body perishes”* (Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 82). In an age of moral relativism, this verse serves as a timeless reminder that divine truth requires courage to defend, patience to uphold, and clarity to distinguish right from wrong.

The command to “be patient for the decision of your Lord” is interpreted as an affirmation of *tawakkul* (trust in divine wisdom) and a rejection of haste in seeking worldly resolutions. Tabatabai emphasizes that patience here transcends passive endurance; it signifies active perseverance in upholding truth amid persecution, reflecting the Shia theological principle of *thabat* (firmness in faith) exemplified by the Ahl al-Bayt (a).

25.layer1:
The verse "وَٱذْكُرِ ٱسْمَ رَبِّكَ بُكْرَةًۭ وَأَصِيلًۭا" (And mention the name of your Lord [in prayer] morning and evening) from Surah Al-Insaan emphasises the centrality of *dhikr* (remembrance of Allah) in a believer’s daily rhythm. The Arabic terms *bukrah* (morning) and *aseel* (evening) denote specific times linked to dawn and sunset, periods Shia traditions associate with heightened spiritual awareness. Classical tafsir, such as Allamah Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan*, explains that this verse urges Muslims to anchor their day in Allah’s remembrance through prayer and reflection, aligning with the Prophet’s (saw) and Ahlul Bayt’s emphasis on *salat al-fajr* (dawn prayer) and *salat al-maghrib* (sunset prayer). These prayers symbolise renewal and gratitude, framing the day within divine consciousness.  

Historically, this verse was revealed in Madinah during a period when the Muslim community was establishing rituals of worship. The Ahlul Bayt, particularly Imam Ali (as), taught that *dhikr* transcends mere repetition; it is a state of heart that transforms actions into worship. The phrase "اسم ربك" (name of your Lord) underscores invoking Allah’s attributes—like *Ar-Rahman* (The Merciful) and *Al-Khaliq* (The Creator)—to cultivate humility and purpose.  

In modern life, this verse invites Muslims to bookend their days with mindfulness of Allah despite busy schedules. Practical applications include prioritising morning and evening prayers, reciting short *adhkar* (supplications) during commutes, or reflecting on Allah’s blessings before sleep. Scholars like Ayatollah Makarem Shirazi highlight that consistent *dhikr* fortifies faith against life’s distractions, fostering inner peace and ethical clarity. By integrating these moments of remembrance, believers mirror the Quranic ideal of a life perpetually connected to the Divine, as taught by the Prophet (saw) and his purified progeny.
25.layer2:
In Surah Al-Insaan (76:25), the Divine command to "mention the name of your Lord morning and evening" is interpreted by classical Shia exegetes as encompassing both the outward observance of ritual worship and the inward cultivation of perpetual God-consciousness. Sheikh Tabrisi, in *Majma al-Bayan*, anchors this verse within the framework of daily obligatory prayers (*salat*), identifying "morning" (*bukrah*) as the Fajr prayer and "evening" (*asil*) as Maghrib and Isha prayers. This aligns with Shia jurisprudence, which structures the five daily prayers around these intervals, emphasising their ontological connection to the rhythms of creation and the believer’s spiritual cycle.

However, Allama Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan* expands this understanding metaphysically, arguing that "morning" and "evening" symbolise the soul’s transition from the "night" of worldly neglect to the "dawn" of divine illumination. The verse thus transcends mere ritual timing, urging a continuous state of remembrance (*dhikr*) that permeates all temporal states. This reflects the Shia emphasis on *walayah* (divine guardianship), wherein true worship necessitates aligning one’s inner disposition with the luminous guidance of the Ahl al-Bayt. Imam Jafar al-Sadiq, as cited in classical sources, elucidates that the "name of your Lord" refers not only to verbal invocation but to the existential recognition of Allah’s attributes manifested through His proofs (*hujjah*)—the Imams—who embody the living connection between Creator and creation.

Theologically, Shia commentators link this verse to the concept of *tawhid al-af’al* (unity of divine acts), wherein every ritual act, when performed with sincere intention (*niyyah*), becomes a mirror reflecting the worshipper’s submission to Allah’s will. Thus, the "morning" and "evening" remembrance signifies the believer’s renewal of covenant (*mithaq*) with the Divine at each existential threshold, harmonising temporal practice with eternal truth. This integrative approach—binding jurisprudence to spirituality and intellect to devotion—epitomises the Shia hermeneutical tradition, where ritual obligation and gnostic realisation are inseparable dimensions of a unified sacred reality.
25.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah Al-Insaan 76:25 is often framed as a call to integrate divine consciousness into the rhythm of daily life. Ayatollah Nasir Makarim Shirazi, in his *Tafsir-e Namune*, highlights how the "morning and evening" remembrance transcends ritualism, urging believers to anchor their actions in *Tawhid* (divine unity) amid modernity’s distractions. Scholars like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali connect this verse to neuroscience, noting how structured prayer times align with circadian rhythms, fostering mental clarity and emotional resilience—a harmony between spiritual practice and biological design that modern psychology increasingly validates.

Socially, the verse speaks to today’s fragmented world. Sheikh Hamza Sodagar emphasises its relevance in countering isolation and anxiety by framing *dhikr* (remembrance) as communal solidarity—whether through collective prayers or digital platforms fostering global spiritual networks. Philosophically, thinkers like Prof. Liyakat Takim interpret "morning and evening" as metaphors for life’s dualities: joy and grief, success and failure, each requiring gratitude or patience rooted in Allah’s name. This duality resonates in addressing crises like climate change, where ethical stewardship (rooted in divine responsibility) meets urgent action.

Interfaith dialogues draw parallels: Buddhist mindfulness and Jewish *Shacharit/Arvit* prayers mirror Islam’s temporal spirituality. Multiculturally, the verse’s emphasis on consistency offers a counter-narrative to consumerist immediacy, advocating for intentional living. In an era of algorithmic distraction, the "bukrah wa aseel" (morning and evening) rhythm becomes a revolutionary act—reclaiming time from capitalist efficiency to nurture transcendent purpose. Thus, the verse bridges ancient discipline with modern self-care, urging believers to weave remembrance into the fabric of existence, transforming mundane moments into acts of sacred resistance.
25.layer4:
The command to "mention the Name of your Lord morning and evening" carries profound spiritual secrets in the light of Ahlul Bayt’s teachings. Imam Ali al-Ridha (as) explains that "morning" (bukrah) refers to Fajr prayer and "evening" (aseel) signifies Maghrib prayer, emphasizing that these times are portals to divine proximity when "the veils between creation and the Creator are thinnest" (Bihar al-Anwar). The verse thus invites believers to anchor their days in the remembrance (dhikr) of Allah through ritual prayer, which the Imams describe as the "ascension of the believer" (Mi’raj al-Mu’min).  

Lady Fatimah (as) taught that true dhikr transcends mere verbal repetition; it is the heart’s awakening to Allah’s presence in every breath. In her famed *Tasbih*, she transformed daily chores into acts of worship, demonstrating how remembrance permeates all aspects of life. The 6th Imam, Jafar al-Sadiq (as), links this verse to the concept of *Wilayah*: "Whoever remembers Allah through us has truly remembered Him." Here, the Names of Allah are inseparable from the luminous reality of the Ahlul Bayt, who are the manifest Names and the means of divine connection.  

Practically, the Imams urged reciting *Dua al-Ashar* (Supplication of the Dawn) at sunrise and *Ziyarat Ashura* at sunset, weaving the remembrance of Allah with love for the Holy Household. Morning and evening thus symbolize the cyclical journey from darkness to light—a purification of the soul through allegiance (*tawalla*) to the Guides (Imamah) and dissociation (*tabarra*) from falsehood. To embody this verse is to let the heart beat in rhythm with the *dhikr* of the Chosen Ones, transforming time itself into a mirror reflecting eternity.

25.layer5:
The interpretation of Surah al-Insan 76:25, which commands believers to "mention the name of your Lord morning and evening," reveals both shared principles and nuanced differences between Shia and Sunni exegetical traditions. Across both traditions, scholars universally emphasize the centrality of *dhikr* (remembrance of God) in spiritual life. Al-Tabari (Sunni) and al-Tabrisi (Shia) concur that the verse underscores the obligation to maintain constant awareness of the Divine through regular worship, aligning "morning and evening" with the five daily prayers (Tabari, *Jami al-Bayan*; Tabrisi, *Majma al-Bayan*). Ibn Kathir (Sunni) and al-Tusi (Shia) similarly highlight the ethical dimension, viewing the verse as a call to integrate gratitude and devotion into daily routines (Ibn Kathir, *Tafsir*; Tusi, *At-Tibyan*).  

Divergences emerge in theological emphasis and ritual application. Sunni commentators like al-Qurtubi (*Al-Jami li-Ahkam*) often link the verse specifically to *salat al-fajr* (dawn prayer) and *salat al-asr* (afternoon prayer), grounding this in Prophetic traditions that prioritize these times. In contrast, Shia exegetes such as al-Qummi (*Tafsir al-Qummi*) and Tabatabai (*Al-Mizan*) extend the interpretation to include supererogatory acts (*nawafil*) and the broader concept of *wilayah* (spiritual guardianship), reflecting the Shia emphasis on the Imams’ teachings as a guide to divine remembrance. Al-Razi (Sunni) offers a philosophical perspective in *Mafatih al-Ghayb*, framing "morning and evening" as symbols of life’s cyclical nature and the soul’s renewal, while Shia sources often associate these times with supplications transmitted through the Ahl al-Bayt.  

Historically, these differences stem from distinct approaches to textual authority: Sunni exegesis prioritizes Prophetic *hadith* and consensus (*ijma*), whereas Shia tradition integrates the Imams’ hermeneutical role. Both interpretations, however, reinforce the verse’s core message: sustaining a conscious connection with the Divine through disciplined practice, reflecting Islam’s universal call to spiritual mindfulness.

The verse "وَٱذْكُرِ ٱسْمَ رَبِّكَ بُكْرَةًۭ وَأَصِيلًۭا" (And mention the name of your Lord [in prayer] morning and evening) from Surah Al-Insaan emphasises the centrality of *dhikr* (remembrance of Allah) in a believer’s daily rhythm. The Arabic terms *bukrah* (morning) and *aseel* (evening) denote specific times linked to dawn and sunset, periods Shia traditions associate with heightened spiritual awareness. Classical tafsir, such as Allamah Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan*, explains that this verse urges Muslims to anchor their day in Allah’s remembrance through prayer and reflection, aligning with the Prophet’s (saw) and Ahlul Bayt’s emphasis on *salat al-fajr* (dawn prayer) and *salat al-maghrib* (sunset prayer). Imam Ali al-Ridha (as) explains that "morning" (bukrah) refers to Fajr prayer and "evening" (aseel) signifies Maghrib prayer, emphasizing that these times are portals to divine proximity when "the veils between creation and the Creator are thinnest" (Bihar al-Anwar). This verse invites Muslims to bookend their days with mindfulness of Allah despite busy schedules.
25.layer2short: In Surah Al-Insaan (76:25), the Divine command to "mention the name of your Lord morning and evening" is interpreted by classical Shia exegetes as encompassing both the outward observance of ritual worship and the inward cultivation of perpetual God-consciousness. Sheikh Tabrisi, in *Majma al-Bayan*, anchors this verse within the framework of daily obligatory prayers (*salat*), identifying "morning" (*bukrah*) as the Fajr prayer and "evening" (*asil*) as Maghrib and Isha prayers. This aligns with Shia jurisprudence, which structures the five daily prayers around these intervals, emphasising their ontological connection to the rhythms of creation and the believer’s spiritual cycle.

26.layer1:
In Surah Al-Insaan (76:26), Allah commands believers: *"Wa minal-layli fasjud lahu wa sabbih-hu laylan taweela"*—"And during the night prostrate to Him and exalt Him a long [part of] the night." This verse emphasizes the profound spiritual connection cultivated through nighttime worship, a theme deeply rooted in Shia tradition. The *sajd* (prostration) here signifies complete submission to Allah, while *tasbeeh* (glorification) involves acknowledging His perfection through phrases like *Subhanallah*. The phrase *laylan taweela* ("a long night") underscores the value of sustained devotion, encouraging believers to dedicate significant time to prayer and reflection beyond obligatory acts.

Historical context reveals this verse was revealed in Medina, where Muslims faced both societal challenges and the need for inner strength. Shia tafsir, such as Allamah Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan*, links this to the Ahlul Bayt’s teachings on night worship as a means of spiritual resilience. Imam Ali (AS) and Imam Sajjad (AS) were known for their lengthy night prayers, embodying this Quranic ideal. Nighttime, free from worldly distractions, is seen as a sacred space for intimate dialogue with Allah, seeking forgiveness (*istighfar*), and aligning one’s heart with divine will.

In modern life, this verse invites Muslims to carve out moments of stillness amid busy schedules. While not all can pray the entire night, even brief acts—like reciting Quran, performing *Salat al-Layl* (night prayer), or reflecting on Allah’s greatness before dawn—fulfill this call. Night worship fosters humility, self-awareness, and gratitude, countering the noise of materialism and stress. For Shia Muslims, it also connects to the legacy of the Imams, who turned to prayer during trials, showing that spiritual discipline anchors the soul in every era. By embracing this practice, believers nurture a living relationship with Allah, transforming darkness into light.
26.layer2:
In Surah al-Insan (76:26), the command to prostrate and glorify Allah during the night is interpreted by classical Shia scholars as an exhortation to cultivate spiritual vigilance and intimate communion with the Divine. Both Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* and Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan* emphasize that this verse underscores the necessity of night worship (*qiyam al-layl*) as a means of attaining proximity (*qurb*) to Allah, a central theological concept in Shia spirituality. Tabrisi notes that the phrase "a long [part of the] night" (*laylan tawila*) refers not merely to duration but to the depth of devotion, urging believers to dedicate the latter portion of the night (the time of *sahar* or pre-dawn) for prayer and reflection, when distractions diminish and divine mercy is most accessible.

Tabatabai elaborates that prostration (*sujud*) here symbolizes total submission to Allah’s will, reflecting the Shia ethos of aligning one’s actions with divine guardianship (*wilayah*). The act of glorification (*tasbih*) is tied to the recognition of Allah’s transcendence, a theme recurrent in the supplications of the Ahl al-Bayt, particularly in the *Sahifa al-Sajjadiyya* of Imam Zayn al-Abidin. Classical commentaries link this verse to the Shia emphasis on supererogatory prayers (*nawafil*), which are seen as complementary to obligatory acts and a means of spiritual refinement. Jurisprudentially, scholars like Shaykh al-Tusi in *Al-Tibyan* derive from this verse the recommendation to prolong night prayers, particularly during the "night of decree" (*Laylat al-Qadr*), which holds heightened significance in Shia practice.

Theologically, this verse resonates with the Shia understanding of human purpose: to transcend worldly attachments through sustained worship, guided by the luminous example of the Imams. The "long night" thus becomes a metaphor for the believer’s lifelong journey toward divine proximity, illuminated by the teachings of the Ahl al-Bayt.
26.layer3:
In Surah Al-Insan 76:26, the call to prostrate and glorify Allah during the "long night" resonates deeply in contemporary Shia discourse, blending spiritual discipline with modern existential challenges. Scholars like Ayatollah Naser Makarem Shirazi emphasize that night worship (*qiyam al-layl*) is not merely ritual but a transformative act of *tawhid* (divine unity), grounding believers in humility amid a fragmented, materialistic world. Sheikh Mohammed Ali Shomali, a contemporary Shia thinker, links this verse to the concept of *mindfulness*—arguing that the stillness of night offers a unique space for introspection, aligning with psychological studies on the benefits of meditation and nocturnal reflection for mental clarity and emotional resilience.  

Modern science underscores the circadian rhythm’s role in regulating human health, with research suggesting that late-night spiritual practices may enhance neuroplasticity and stress management—a synergy of faith and biology. Socially, the verse speaks to today’s crisis of disconnection. In an age of digital overload, the "long night" becomes a metaphor for reclaiming time from the tyranny of screens, fostering spiritual and communal bonds.  

Globally, the verse invites interfaith dialogue. Jewish *Tikkun Chatzot* (midnight lamentations) and Christian midnight prayers share parallels with Islamic night vigils, highlighting a universal human yearning for transcendence. For marginalized communities, night worship embodies resistance—a quiet defiance against systemic injustice, as seen in the spiritual resilience of persecuted Shia minorities.  

Ultimately, this verse challenges believers to balance activism with inner renewal, merging classical devotion with modern imperatives of justice, mental health, and ecological stewardship—a timeless call to harmonize the soul’s needs with the world’s brokenness.
26.layer4:
The verse from Surah Al-Insaan calls believers to immerse themselves in the profound stillness of the night, transforming darkness into luminous communion with the Divine. The Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) taught that night vigil (*salat al-layl*) is the "crown of worship" and a sacred inheritance from the Prophet Muhammad (pbuh), who said, "The best prayer after the obligatory ones is the prayer performed in the depths of the night" (Imam Ali, *Nahj al-Balagha*). Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (pbuh) illuminated this verse’s inner dimension, stating, "The one who prostrates in the long night is he whose heart is illuminated by the light of *Wilayah* [divine guardianship], for prostration is the key to nearness, and glorification [*tasbih*] is the polishing of the soul."

Lady Fatimah (pbuh) exemplified this practice, spending her nights in prayer and whispering supplications that merged fear, love, and hope. Her *Tasbih*—the rhythmic remembrance of Allah—was not mere repetition but a ladder ascending to divine presence. The Imams taught that prolonged night worship nurtures *taqwa* (God-consciousness) and aligns the believer’s will with the cosmic order upheld by the *Imamah*. Imam Ali (pbuh) advised, "Let your night be longer in prostration and your tongue sweeter in glorification, for these are the weapons of the lovers of Allah."

Practically, the Ahlul Bayt urged believers to awaken in the *sahar* (pre-dawn hours), when divine mercy descends. Reciting *Duha* prayers, reflecting on Quranic verses, and seeking forgiveness (*istighfar*) during this time purify the soul and fortify one’s bond with the Imam of the Age (ajtf). The "long night" thus becomes a metaphor for spiritual endurance: a journey from ritual to reality, where prostration becomes annihilation in Allah’s unity, and *tasbih* echoes the eternal harmony of creation. As Imam al-Baqir (pbuh) said, "The night is a treasure; its worshippers are the heirs.

26.layer5:
The verse's call to nocturnal prostration and glorification (sujud wa tasbih) finds shared spiritual significance across traditions. Both Shia and Sunni exegetes, including Tabatabai (Al-Mizan) and Ibn Kathir, interpret this as an exhortation to voluntary night worship (qiyam al-layl), emphasizing its role in spiritual refinement and proximity to God. Classical sources universally link this to the Prophet’s nocturnal devotions, with Tabari noting its alignment with Quranic praises of those "who forsake their beds" (32:16). Qurtubi and Tusi both highlight the verse’s ethical dimension, framing night prayer as a means to cultivate humility and gratitude.  

Divergences emerge in theological emphasis and ritual particulars. Sunni commentators like Razi (Mafatih al-Ghayb) often contextualize the injunction as a general encouragement for supererogatory prayers, stressing individual spiritual discipline. In contrast, Shia tafsirs such as Majma al-Bayan (Tabrisi) and Al-Qummi frequently tie the verse to the Ahlul Bayt’s teachings, interpreting "long night" as a specific allusion to the predawn (sahar) vigil emphasized by Imam Ali and his successors. Al-Mizan further frames nocturnal worship as a means of cosmic alignment with the divine will, reflecting the Shia emphasis on the Imam’s role as a spiritual guide.  

These distinctions subtly influence practice: Sunni traditions often prioritize communal Tarawih prayers (in Ramadan) alongside individual Tahajjud, while Shia devotional norms stress solitary sahar prayers linked to the Imams’ supplications. Historically, these differences stem from variant epistemological frameworks—Sunni reliance on Prophetic precedent transmitted by companions, versus Shia reliance on the Imams’ hermeneutical authority.  

Both traditions ultimately converge on the verse’s core message: that sustained nocturnal worship embodies profound submission to God, transcending sectarian boundaries in its universal call to spiritual awakening.

26.layer2short: In Surah al-Insan (76:26), the command to prostrate and glorify Allah during the night is interpreted by classical Shia scholars as an exhortation to cultivate spiritual vigilance and intimate communion with the Divine. Both Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* and Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan* emphasize that this verse underscores the necessity of night worship (*qiyam al-layl*) as a means of attaining proximity (*qurb*) to Allah, a central theological concept in Shia spirituality.
